intro: Psammogeton microcarpum, commonly known as the small-fruited sandmat, is a low-growing perennial plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its succulent, fleshy leaves and small, club-shaped fruits. The plant thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is adapted to withstand drought conditions. It produces tiny, pale green flowers that are typically inconspicuous and clustered in dense inflorescences. Psammogeton microcarpum plays a role in stabilizing sandy soils and is sometimes used in xeriscaping due to its drought tolerance.
